In this case, "If the bear was in the cave (P), then the wolf was in the den (Q). The bear was not in the cave (not P). Therefore, the wolf was not in the den (not Q)." However, the conclusion does not follow from the premises in this case. The first premise only tells us that if the bear was in the cave, then the wolf was in the den. It does not tell us that the wolf was not in the den if the bear was not in the cave. Therefore, the argument is not logically valid.
